org.apache.taverna.security.credentialmanager

Interface TrustConfirmationProvider


  • public interface TrustConfirmationProvider
    Defines an interface for providing ways to confirm/decline trust in a given service (i.e. its public key certificate).

    Used by Credential Manager when looking up the username and password for the service in its Keystore - if it cannot find anything it will loop through all providers until one can provide them. If none can, the service invocation will (most probably) fail.

    A typical implementation of this class would pop up a dialog and ask the user for the password. Such providers should check GraphicsEnvironment#isHeadless() before returning to avoid attempts to pop up dialogues on server/headless installations.

    It is safe to return null if the provider does not have an opinion.

    Author:
    Alex Nenadic, Stian Soiland-Reyes
    See Also:
    CredentialManager

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      Boolean shouldTrustCertificate(X509Certificate[] chain)
      If the given public key certificate should be trusted or not.

    • Method Detail

      • shouldTrustCertificate

        Boolean shouldTrustCertificate(X509Certificate[] chain)
        If the given public key certificate should be trusted or not.

        This method is called when a SSL connection is attempted to a service which certificate could not be confirmed using the Credential Manager's Truststore (i.e. it could not be found there).

        A typical implementation of this class would pop up a dialog and ask the user if they want to trust the service. Such providers should check GraphicsEnvironment#isHeadless() before returning to avoid attempts to pop up dialogues on server/headless installations.

        The provider can return null if it does not have an opinion whether the certificate should be trusted or not (in which case other providers will be asked), or an instance of TrustConfirmation confirming or denying if the certificate is to be trusted.

        If the provider returns true, the Credential Manager will also save the first certificate of the certificate chain (chain[0]) in its Truststore so the user will not be asked next time.

        Parameters:
        chain - X509 certificate chain to confirm whether it is trusted or not
        Returns:
        null if the provider does not have an opinion, true if certificate is to be trusted and false if not.
